markdownRemark.html:
If you know me personally, you probably know why I am interested in studying Marxism. There are things that I cannot understand under the current system on how majority of the world runs (aka capitalism). I set out to explore how Marxism view capitalism and what the lessons are to be learned. Fun fact, undergraduates in most Chinese university are required to study Marxism!

This blog serves as my journal on how I studied Marxism. I will also be sharing my notes and providing links to the resources I used.

Now, where do we start? I found this article from the NYU professor Bertell Ollman titled ”On Teaching Marixsm”. I used it as the backbone of my own humble syllabus. It also makes some great points about the challenges faced when teaching Marxism in an American universities. The three factors are (1) the default materialistic ideology of the students, (2) the social and ideological constraints that are part of university setting (the fact that we live in a capitalist society), and (3) the absence of a vital socialist movement. Understand these constraints hopefully help me to resolve any bias before going into the study, such that I can appreciate Marxism better.

Professor Bertell also emphasized three main aspects of Marxism in the article: (1) the dialectics, (2) the theory of class struggle, and (3) Marx’s critique of bourgeois ideology. I will attempt to follow the framework as a guide to my study.

Dialectics

First, we start off with dialectics. According to the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, dialectics is describes “a method of philosophical argument that involves some sort of contradictory process between opposing sides”. How I understand it, with a bad deep learning analogy, is that dialectics resembles the process of a generative adversary network (GAN). Two opposing values try to argue against each other, but both party learn from the other party as well. I don’t recommend reading into the Encyclopedia too much. As a newbie in philosophy, the terms are hard to understand.

More specifically, the study of Marxism employs the Hegelian dialectic. Here is a video of Hegelian dialectic by The School of Life. It looks at it from a historical perspective but gives a good sense of what dialectic feels like.

Another good introduction to Hegelian dialectics is one by Philosophy Tube. It covers the Hegelian dialectics and how identity politics can be explained through the lens of Hegel, but also some criticism about Hegel’s method.

Now, this is just an introduction to Hegelian dialectic. To tie it back to Marx, professor Ollman wrote an entire book, called the “Dance of the Dialectic”, on dialectics analysis in Marxism. Dialectics in Marxism itself is a complex subject in which a quarter/semester of time can be spent on studying it. To get a quick grasp, read the introduction chapter of the book.

The chapter points out something that runs contradicts from the previous videos on introduction to Hegelian dialectics, and I quote:

Dialectics is not a rock-ribbed triad of thesis-antithesis- synthesis that serves as an all-purpose explanation; nor does it provide a formula that enables us to prove or predict anything; nor is it the motor force of history.

However, I don’t think this is a contradiction between different sources. In this chapter, professor Ollman is stressing that dialectics is the method that Marx used to study any subject.

Professor Ollman explains how Marx disregards perception as evidence of truth, meaning whatever we see, hear, smell, feel cannot be based off to form our understanding. Even those these measures are taken scientifically or processed error-free in a computer. The argument is that on a viewer draws conclusion from what the viewer perceive an entity is greatly affected by the environment. More importantly, the viewer themselves can be affected by their own context. Example, a capitalist might see a machine as a thing that makes him money, but a worker might see a machine as a thing that guides the worker’s movement during production.

This brings to how fundamentally Marx understands the world. Instead of stand-alone event, institution, person, or process, they are all connected and affects each other. This means Marx looks at the world as a connected whole.

Fact/Value Distinction

What follows very naturally from Marx’s distrust in perception is his dispute of the fact and value distinction. We think of “fact” as something always true in universally and always holds under any condition. According the Marx then, so such thing called “fact” can exist since nothing can be interpreted to be the identical under any context. Everything we think of as fact is still influenced by our value, or what we think to be true, and how we perceive it.

This article gives a good explanation on the fact/value distinction. It is long and clobbered with philosophy terms and requires some solid background. Therefore, I would recommend reading the introductory section to grasp the overall idea. Then move on to the first (“Two Versions of the Fact/Value Distinction”) and second (“Critiques of the Fact/Value Distinction”) section to understand what the distinction is and how it is disputed. After, that jumps to the “Ethical Naturalism and Sociology” section and read how Marx argued against the fact/value distinction.

Notes: poli sci 118 lec 10

  • the structure of micro-story/macro-story and the invisible hand theory
  • assumption: the ultimate good with most value is personal freedom

  • the antithesis of freedom by Marx: unfreedom

    • as soon as we have division of labor, we are no longer free
    • we are forever trapped in the sphere of an exclusive activity
    • we are alienated from our true self
    • we can only reach freedom under the enormous abundance of wealth (?)

  • Marx is a objectivist, believes in objectivism

    • materialist conception of history shapes the way history unfold
    • it predicts how capitalism will play out its conflict
    • reductionism
    • political actions are determined by economic interest
    • class in itself vs class for itself

    • Marx is an individualist, despite he considers thing on a class level

      • he defines classes by how individuals relate to the mean of production

    • class-in-itself: you are working a nice high paying job living in nice houses, you are still part of the working class, regardless if you understand it or not.

      • objective division of class
    • class-for-itself: if you don’t believe that you are working class, then you are not working class.
    • Marx thinks what ultimately drives conflict and development is class-in-itself, regardless of how subject perceives it, it is objective.
    • utopia situation: people will realize that objectively what class they are in, meaning class-in-itself equals class-for-itself
    • question: working class can also now buy stocks, they are capitalist, but also working class
    • simple-minded according to Marx’s classification of working vs capitalist class?
    • if you need to work to survive, then you are working class (aka financial freedom)

  • source of value is work/labor

    • social necessary labor time (SNLT): labor time required to produce use-value (anything with utility) under the conditions of production normal for a given society and with the average degree of skill and intensity of the labor prevalent in the society.
    • making things twice as fast/slow is socially unneeded labor, we focus on the average
    • equilibrium price of commodity is determined by the amount of SNLT went into that commodity
    • the labor theory of surplus value
    • def: living human labor-power is the only source of fresh value
    • all commodity is result of human work

    • labor is also a kind of commodity, wages are determined by the cost to produce the labor, not by the value that the labor produces

      • if so, why is celebrity get paid so much?
      • the max cost is determined by the max amount of time in a day
      • but there are cost that are paid not by the labor itself but by other parties
      • other people that didn’t end up becoming celebrities
      • winner-take-all market (Marx didn’t offer the best explanation for that)
    • consumption of labor power retains value, not like other commodity (like food)
    • constant capital (everything else but wages) vs variable capital (wages)

    • why variable? wages are always driven to subsistence (empirical assumption of Marxism)

      • there are always unemployed in society
      • hire unemployed non-union worker with wages lower than union worker
      • called “reserved army of unemployed”
      • subsistence: changes
    • C=c+vC = c + vC=c+v (total capital equals constant capital plus wages)

  • rate of exploitation

    • let’s say a worker works 10 hours a day, 4 hours of work creates enough value for the worker’s wages, the left over 6 hours is the surplus labor time
    • the rate of exploitation is in this case 6/4 = 1.5.
    • the capitalist can increase working hours, so there is more surplus and more exploitation
    • there is an upper limit to which hours can be increased
    • new way: advancing technology, making labor produce more efficiently, lowers the number of labor hours needed to cover the wage, so rate of exploitation increase.
    • result: constant pressure of technological innovation
    • you spent more money on constant capital instead of wages
    • production becomes more capital intensive
    • you are spending more and more money on something that does not produce real value (non-labor)

  • half ending ideas for next lecture:

    • Marx’s assumption: people determine how well off they are compared to others
    • sociology shows that yes, people are other-referential when comparing wealth-off-ness, but only with people in similar situation

Notes: socy 151 lec 9

  • difference between ideologist vs materialist

    • ideologist believes that ideas explains human being, some greater being like God created those ideas
    • materialist starts from material condition tries to explain the idea from the material condition
  • the first 34 minutes was the life of Marx. offers some shallow background to Marx’s work and his intersection with history in Europe

  • 4 characteristics of alienation

    1. from object of production
    2. the object which labor produces – labor’s product – confronts the worker as something alien, as a power independent of power.
    3. by contrast, the work by artist, by shoe maker, etc., their work are not alienated. They identify the work, they might have license or copyright over their work
    4. in the act of production
    5. labor is external to the worker, i.e. it does not belong to his intrinsic nature, in his work he does not affirm himself but denies himself. The worker does not freely develop his physical and mental energy
    6. labor is not voluntary, but forced
    7. men’s activity belongs to somebody else
    8. from species being (what makes us different from animal)
    9. nature and human spiritual species property into a being alien to him
    10. alienated from the human essence
    11. from fellow men
    12. treat each other as object
  • (was a bad lecture, he admitted it in the next lecture)

Notes: socy 151 lec 10

  • there were two “Marx”. The early Marx and the old Marx
  • Marx’s Theory of Alienation is lays ground for other social theories. Therefore it is very important.

  • Hegel: consciousness precedes materialist existence, therefore Hegel is idealist

    • totality: the Absolute Spirit is the object and subject itself, unity of object and subject
    • you can describe universe as the alienation/separation between the subject and the object
    • when consciousness emerge, we control objective condition of our life, so subject and object overlaps
    • not condition that rules you, you rule the condition

  • Marx: alienation of subject and object under modern condition materialistically

    • Marx eliminated the concept of Absolute Spirit
    • Marx was bothered by the fact that alienation can be conquered by thoughts and consciousness
    • this is primarily why young Marx’s theory of alienation survived longer than old Marx’s theory of exploitation
    • this is relatable since we are all alienated from developing our own personality. we are constantly forced to do things

  • Marx’s Critique of Hegel’s Philosophy of Right

    • Hegel: expect the government to represent an universal interest
    • Marx: Hegel is naive about the government. Govt is not non-partial
    • the rich has more power over the government than the poor
    • big business have more leverage over the lobbyist
    • state is not universal, it is only the appearance of universalism
    • civil servants are not the “universal class”
    • Marx is dissatisfied with universal suffrage
    • we have all equal votes but not equal rights

  • The path of intellectual projection of young Marx

    • On the Jewish Question: claims we need an universal interest
    • In Introduction to Critique of Hegel’s Philosophy of Right, he points out the proletariat should carry out universal emancipation
    • Marx’s critics question the intelligence of working class cannot lead the society
    • Marx therefore wrote the Paris Manuscript to bring in the economic element and ties to the commodity production mode of society
    • the theory of alienation comes from here

  • On the Jewish Question:

    • Bruno Bauer says the state is christian therefore it always discriminate the Jews
    • To abolish anti-Semitism, we separate the state and the church (political emancipation)
    • Marx claims it’s wrong since in the US state and church is separate but still anti-Semitism
    • anti-semitism comes from the civil society because some people feels threatened by the Jews
    • state is not at fault but in civil society. therefore we need universal emancipation

Notes: socy 151 lec 11

  • The German Ideology: Marx arguing how capitalist will come to an end and how Marx becomes a economic determinist and historical materialist

    • the materialist view of history
    • theory of modes of production
    • forces/relations of production and division of labor
    • human history: subsequent modes of production
    • sociology of knowledge

    • life determine consciousness (materialism)

      • your material desire determines your social and political relations
    • ruling class determines the ruling ideas

Notes: socy 151 lec 12

  • many facets of Karl Marx

    • young Hegelian that was an ideologist
    • rejection of Hegelian and becoming a materialist

  • In German Ideology, Marx introduce the idea of modes of production

    • human distinguish themselves from animals as soon as they begin to produce
    • changing the world to fit their needs = human

  • from German Ideology to the Grundrisse

    1. German Ideology: history is driven by increasing division of labor; Grundrisse: history is a movement towards private ownership, gradual separation of laboring subject and objective conditions of labor
    2. German Ideology: unilinear view of history (all society starts from the same point of tribal society. And all will end in communism through capitalism); Grundrisse: mutliple trajectories.

  • Centrality of division of labor in German Ideology: Marx describes each mode of production with the dialectic interaction between

    • forces of production (technology, raw materials, labor power)
    • relationships of production (tends to identify this with property relations)
    • e.g. existing stage in the division of labor determines also the relations of individuals to one another (property relations)

  • different modes of production (German Ideology)

    • tribalism
    • hunting and fishing
    • elementary division of labor
    • confined to natural division of labor between men and women
    • slavery
    • union of tribes into a city
    • class relations between citizens and slaves are now completely developed
    • feudalism
    • has to force the labor to work
    • slaves replaced by serfs and peasants
    • capitalism
    • Marx breaks away from intercourse = division of labor
    • develop concept of relations of production

  • Forces and relations of production (Grundrisse)

    • each mode of production can be characterized by the correspondence of forces and relations of production
    • forces of production tend to develop, eventually they “outgrow” the old relations of production
    • new relations of production merge in the wombs of the old mode of production; revolution changes the mode of production

  • new contributions of Grundrisse

    • evolution of modes of productions: changes in property relations
    • pre-capitalist forms: the objective condition of labor is treated as the labor’s own individual condition
    • private ownership is defined as a complete separation of laboring subject and objective conditions of labor: alienation
    • transition to capitalism: separation of workers and the conditions of work
    • after tribalism there are various routes societies can make (non unilinear)
    • Marx said he was wrong. It was not class struggle that always drive the change. It can also be external forces

Notes: scoy 151 lec 13

  • Marx’s major contribution: theory of exploitation
  • from the book Capital

  • theory of exploitation:

    • labor theory of value
    • Marx radicalizes Adam Smith theory. All value is created by labor
    • (side track to Adam Smith): rent seeking behavior is associated with monopolies. therefore we don’t like rent
    • modern day social scientist abandon labor theory of value
    • what is value: c + v + s
    • constant capital + variable capital (wages) + surplus (surplus to earn for capitalist)
    • constant capital = investment (consistent with Adam Smith)
    • Marx: constant capital is accumulated labor
    • exploitation comes from the surplus
    • rate of profit is s / (c + v)
    • from petty commodity production to capitalist mode of production
    • petty commodity production C-M-C: (1) create a Commodity (2) sell the commodity on the Market (3) buy a Commodity
    • production of some goods in excess is to satisfy the needs for other goods
    • in comparison to young Marx, who tried to derive alienation from the process of market exchange, old Marx now sees that market exchange in C-M-C can also exist without exploitation
    • capitalist production M-C-M’: (1) accumulated capital in the market (2) produce commodity (3) accumulate more capital
    • purpose of production is not satisfaction of needs but generation of profit, capitalist forced to strive for it by competition with fellow capitalist
    • the most altruistic capitalist still have to collect more money. without more capital the competition will wipe out the capitalist
    • labor power as commodity
    • how did the more money come from?
    • capitalist does not cheat to underpay the labor, equals value are still exchanged (so supply and demand still holds in the market)
    • capitalist buy labor power, which is different from labor.
    • the price paid to labor power is exactly how much is necessary to reproduce that labor power
    • but when labor power is a unique commodity that when consumed, it can create more value than its own value.
    • exploitation is not evil, but inevitable in capitalism

  • classes in history (Communist Manifesto)

    • classes as a trans-historical category
    • class struggle drives progress of history
    • not true 100% as validated in history
    • Marx did acknowledge the progressive role of the bourgeoisie

  • how many classes are there?

    • bourgeoisie and proletariat
    • middle classes? Marx predicted that middle class will vanish
    • but actually there has been more middle class in history that Marx did not forsee

Reading for socy 151 lec 9: The Paris Manuscript

  • wages fo labor

    • workers have become a commodity, if supply exceed demand, workers starve

Notes for plsc 118 lec 11

  • absolute surplus value: increasing absolute labor time

    • this has a physical limit in that human needs 8 hours of sleep
  • relative surplus value: making better technology, to increase labor productivity
  • rate of exploitation = surplus labor time (total labor time minus necessary labor time) / necessary labor time (labor time that produces the value of the wages)
  • capital intensity increases over time

  • rate of exploitation ≠ rate of profit

    • surplus covers other costs (rent, R/D, marketing…)
    • profit is a subset of rate of surplus value
  • micro-theory of Marx: theory of exploitation

  • macro-theory of Marx: 5 Part Theory of Crisis

    • money
    • gold/silver money is still commodity
    • it has cost of production, takes work to dig and refine gold
    • people will start to hoard money (liquidity crisis)
    • declining tendency in the rate of profit
    • every one can catch up to the same technology, less labor fresh value
    • decrease the profit of the industry as a whole
    • there is very little margin in some industry
    • monopolies and the elimination of competition
    • a perfectly competitive market will overtime turn into monopoly
    • more capital intensive, entry cost is high
    • under-consumption
    • workers pooled all their wages together can’t buy what they produce
    • weak demand in capitalist economy
    • imperialism is to search for new market
    • (but society is not only composed of workers, is it…)
    • working-class consciousness
    • worker will realize they have nothing to lose but their chain
    • fewer and fewer benefits to workers

  • socialism: a society based on genuine workmanship

    • socialism is also a system with internal contradiction according to Marx
    • we do get what we make
    • inequality exists if we reward based on labor
    • everyone are physically or mentally different
    • production capacity is a natural privilege
    • somebody also have different demands
    • socialism is not equality due to right to labor

  • abolition of right is a precondition to a communist society

    • distribute on basis of needs

  • criticism of Marx

    • capitalism manufactures pseudo-wants all the time, demands that nobody needs
    • these needs will go away when capitalism goes away
    • people will have finite needs
    • core criticism: the concept of superabundance from capitalism is not real
    • any choice to spend money in A will prevent money being spent in B and C
    • world is still in scarcity
